title: Soccer
text:
Soccer has been one of the most defining parts of my life. I played NCAA Division I soccer for four years, and those years shaped me as an athlete, a leader, a teammate, and a person. When I committed to play at the collegiate level, I moved to a state where I didn‚Äôt know anyone; no friends, no family nearby, and everything completely new. That decision ended up giving me a community that felt like home.
My team was made up of players from all over the world, which meant every practice, bus ride, and meal introduced me to new cultures, new perspectives, and even new languages. Those teammates became lifelong friends, and the experience opened my world far beyond the field.
I played my first two seasons at the University of Northern Colorado and my following two seasons at Texas State University. I would not trade that experience for anything. It was an amazing four years.

title: Rocky Mountain Ski and Sport
text:
Rocky Mountain Ski and Sport (RMSS) is a locally owned ski and snowboard shop based in Colorado Springs, Colorado. The shop was founded with a mission to make winter sports more accessible, more sustainable, and more community centered. Instead of encouraging constant gear replacement, RMSS focuses on repairing equipment, extending product lifecycles, and promoting the use of high-quality used gear.
RMSS specializes in:

High-quality used skis, snowboards, boots, and bindings

Professional tuning and repairs to extend equipment life

Safe fittings for riders of all experience levels

Packaging online orders using reused and recycled materials

Providing budget-friendly gear for families, beginners, and experienced riders

Educating the community through in-store expertise and social media content

This combination of sustainability, affordability, and knowledge has made RMSS a trusted resource for skiers and snowboarders across the Colorado Springs and Pueblo region.

title: Rocky Mountain Ski and Sport
section: How Rocky Mountain Ski and Sport Reduces Waste in the Ski Industry
text:
How Rocky Mountain Ski and Sport Reduces Waste in the Ski Industry

Repairing Existing Gear
RMSS performs waxes, tunes, edge sharpening, P-tex repairs, and full safety checks. These repairs keep skis and snowboards riding longer, reducing the need for new manufacturing and minimizing equipment waste.


Reselling Quality Used Equipment
Buying used gear keeps equipment out of landfills, cuts down on emissions tied to production, and makes snow sports accessible to more people. Every used item is inspected, refurbished, and tuned so customers get safe, high-quality gear at a fraction of the cost.


Reusing and Recycling Packaging
From shipping boxes to bubble wrap, RMSS prioritizes reusing and recycling all packing materials. This reduces the environmental footprint of online orders and models sustainable business practices for the ski community.

title: Fountain Creek Watershed District
text:
The Fountain Creek Watershed stretches from the Palmer Divide south through Colorado Springs to where Fountain Creek meets the Arkansas River in Pueblo. It covers about 927 square miles and includes urban areas, open spaces, creeks, wetlands, and important wildlife habitat.
Because so many communities share this creek system, what happens upstream affects people, water quality, and ecosystems downstream. Flooding, erosion, stormwater runoff, and pollution can all travel through the watershed and impact neighborhoods, farms, parks, and recreation areas in both El Paso and Pueblo Counties.

title: Fountain Creek Watershed District
section: What the Fountain Creek Watershed District Does
text:
What the Fountain Creek Watershed District Does
The Fountain Creek Watershed, Flood Control and Greenway District (often shortened to the Fountain Creek Watershed District) was created in 2009 as a special district to protect and improve the health of the watershed.
The District‚Äôs main goals include:

Reducing flood risk by improving drainage, restoring floodplains, and managing stormwater
Limiting erosion and sediment so creek channels and banks stay more stable
Improving water quality for people, wildlife, and recreation
Protecting open space and riparian corridors along Fountain Creek and its tributaries
Creating and supporting trails, parks, and public access along the creek

To do this, the District works with cities, counties, state and federal agencies, nonprofits, and local residents. Projects can include creek bank stabilization, wetland and riparian restoration, trail connections, green infrastructure, and public education.

My Role with the Fountain Creek Watershed District
I support the District through outreach writing and storytelling. My work focuses on helping people understand the connection between everyday choices and the health of the Fountain Creek Watershed.
In practice, that means:

Below is an example of one of my recent articles, written for the District.

title: Fountain Creek Watershed District
section: Featured Article: Sustainable Skiing and Snowboarding in the Fountain Creek Watershed
text:
Featured Article: Sustainable Skiing and Snowboarding in the Fountain Creek Watershed
Winter in Colorado pulls people outside, but it also gives us a chance to think about how our choices impact the watershed we live in. While skiing and snowboarding are winter favorites, it is important to understand the environmental impact it holds. Skiing and snowboarding can be high-impact sports when it comes to waste, transportation, and the strain on mountain environments. With a few intentional choices, we can enjoy the season while keeping our footprint lighter and staying connected to the water systems that support our communities.
One of the biggest steps toward more sustainable winter recreation is choosing quality gear that lasts. Ski and snowboard equipment takes a lot of resources to make, and most riders replace it long before it is truly worn out. Rocky Mountain Ski and Sport in Colorado Springs is a great local example of how to break that cycle. Instead of pushing new gear every season, they specialize in repairing equipment, tuning old boards and skis, using recycled materials, and reselling quality used gear. This keeps equipment out of landfills, makes the sport more affordable and accessible, and reduces the demand for constant manufacturing.
How we get to the slopes is another major factor that leads to emissions. Traffic on winter weekends means more emissions, more road salt runoff, and more impact on the mountain environments where our snowpack eventually becomes the water that feeds the Fountain Creek system. Shared travel is one of the easiest ways to cut that impact. Rocky Mountain Ride offers ski shuttles from downtown Colorado Springs to Monarch, Breckenridge, Keystone, and Arapahoe Basin. They leave from downtown Colorado Springs at 6:30 a.m. and depart from the resort at 3:00 p.m. on select days and make the trip without adding dozens of individual cars to the road. It is also easy to organize carpools from Colorado Springs or Pueblo, which reduces both fuel use and parking pressure at the resorts.
Not every winter adventure has to be a resort trip. Cross country skiing and snowshoeing close to home can be just as rewarding and often have the lowest impact. Trails near water sources help people see the connection between winter recreation and the watershed. Woodmoor Nordic in Monument is a local groomed option, offering classic and skate ski trails supported by a nonprofit that keeps access affordable. There are also several cross country and snowshoe trails in the Colorado Springs and Pueblo areas listed on TrailLink, a website that catalogs walking, hiking, biking, and cross-country ski trails around the country. For a more direct link to local water systems, winter trails around spots like Rampart Reservoir give people a chance to experience snowpack right at the source of our future water supply.
Sustainable winter recreation doesn‚Äôt have to be complicated. Repairing and reusing gear, choosing shared transportation, and exploring nearby trails all help protect the watershed while keeping winter recreation fun and accessible. Each of these choices reduces waste, lowers emissions, and supports the long-term health of the landscapes that make winter in Colorado worth celebrating.

title: Snowboarding
section: Passion for Accessibility in Winter Sports
text:
Passion for Accessibility in Winter Sports
One of my biggest goals is to help make skiing and snowboarding more accessible. Too often, winter sports are viewed as something only the wealthy can participate in. High prices for gear, lift tickets, and travel create real barriers for many people who want to try something new or experience the mountains.
Through my work in the ski industry, and especially at Rocky Mountain Ski and Sport, I am passionate about:

Expanding access to quality used gear

Teaching people about affordable alternatives

Reducing waste and lowering gear costs through repair and reuse

Creating a more welcoming, inclusive culture in winter sports

Encouraging more beginners, families, and young riders to enter the sport

Everyone deserves the chance to experience the confidence, community, and joy that snowboarding brings ‚Äî not just those who can afford high-end equipment or resort prices.

title: Snowboarding
text:
Snowboarding and Mental Health
Snowboarding has helped me stay grounded in difficult times and has become a powerful outlet for managing stress and staying active. It supports mental health by:

Providing a physical challenge that builds confidence

Encouraging mindfulness and presence on the mountain

Reconnecting people with nature and seasonal cycles

Building a community of supportive, like-minded riders

Giving people something joyful and motivating during winter months

For many riders, including me, snowboarding is a form of therapy ‚Äî one built on movement, nature, and progression.

title: Snowboarding
text:
Looking Ahead
Snowboarding is something I want to continue growing in ‚Äî not just as a rider, but as someone who helps others access the sport. Whether through education, sustainable gear practices, or community outreach, I hope to make winter sports more inclusive, more affordable, and more mentally supportive for everyone.
